instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..

threads.title: Corrupted LCD BIOS
threads.message:
In the company we have a lot of <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> screens with similar problems.
There appears to be a problem with the PCB of the screen.

Are there any solutions or devices for calibration?
Most are in very good condition with some random issues like the blue streak in the photo ...

I have already replaced the cable and PCB part by removing the LCD.
This makes the problem worse ... I think it is a corrupt BIOS ...

That's why I ask if there are calibration devices or the like?

This problem did not exist on the retina screens <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ect ... It is really very specific to <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ...

It would be a shame to put all this batch of screens in the trash ...

threads.title: Corrupted LCD BIOS
threads.message: I have been meaning to attempt this repair, I have a 13" lined up ready to get new flex cables + PCB board soldered on. Have you tried JUST replacing the cables and re-using the original PCB?
